value.content:
Firefox supports a number of Mozilla extensions to CSS, including properties, values, pseudo-elements and pseudo-classes, at-rules, and media queries. These extensions are prefixed with -moz-.

Note: These extensions are mostly experimental or deprecated but kept for backward compatibility. Avoid using them on production websites.

value.title: Mozilla-only properties
value.content:
• -moz-box-align Deprecated
  • -moz-box-direction Deprecated
  • -moz-box-flex Deprecated
  • -moz-box-ordinal-group Deprecated
  • -moz-box-orient Deprecated

  • -moz-orient Non-standard
  • -moz-osx-font-smoothing Non-standard
  • -moz-user-focus Non-standard

  • -moz-user-modify Non-standard

value.title: Formerly proprietary properties that are now standard
value.content: Note: To maximize the compatibility of your CSS, you should use the unprefixed standard properties instead of the prefixed ones listed below. Once a given property is standardized and implemented without the prefix, the prefixed version is typically dropped after a while.

toc.text: Formerly proprietary properties that are now standard

doc.summary: Firefox supports a number of Mozilla extensions to CSS, including properties, values, pseudo-elements and pseudo-classes, at-rules, and media queries. These extensions are prefixed with -moz-.
doc.pageTitle: Mozilla vendor-prefixed CSS extensions - CSS: Cascading Style Sheets | MDN
